newsitem.title: SIERRA LEONE: More Lebanese flee Sierra Leone after coup.
newsitem.headline: More Lebanese flee Sierra Leone after coup.

text.p: About 100 Lebanese women and children left troubled Sierra Leone by hovercraft for neighbouring Guinea on Saturday and 1,500 more people scrambled to board a ship hoping to follow them, witnesses said.

The hovercraft was chartered by the Lebanese community in Guinea's capital Conakry and picked up Lebanese who had flown to the Sierra Leone capital of Freetown by helicopter from the eastern town of Bo, organisers said.
A mix of Lebanese and West African nationals clamoured to board the passenger ship Ocean Princess, which had been hired by the Lebanese community and Guinean officials, witnesses and organisers said.
Freetown was calm on Saturday after the May 25 military coup that toppled elected civilian president Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, whose 1996 election ended four years of army rule.
But police sources reported a jump in armed crime, looting and rape. Residents blamed rebels who flooded into the city after rallying behind the coup.
